head.title: Palmer Content to Be Honorary Starter at Masters

hedline.hl1: Palmer Content to Be Honorary Starter at Masters
hedline.hl2: Palmer Content to Be Honorary Starter at Masters

block.p: Three years after Arnold Palmer retired from playing the Masters, he will stand on the first tee Thursday and hit a drive as the tournament's honorary starter. Palmer, a four-time champion, played in 50 consecutive tournaments after making his first appearance in 1955.

''I think the time has come,'' Palmer, 77, said. ''My competitive golf is done. I have no intentions of playing competitively on the Tour. I hope in some way I can show my gratitude to the fans who have followed and supported me these many years.''
Three years after Arnold Palmer retired from playing the Masters, he will stand on the first tee Thursday and hit a drive as the tournamentâ€™s honorary starter.

Three years after Arnold Palmer retired from playing the Masters, he will stand on the first tee Thursday and hit a drive as the tournament's honorary starter. Palmer, a four-time champion, played in 50 consecutive tournaments after making his first appearance in 1955.

''I think the time has come,'' Palmer, 77, said. ''My competitive golf is done. I have no intentions of playing competitively on the Tour. I hope in some way I can show my gratitude to the fans who have followed and supported me these many years.''

Billy Payne, the Augusta chairman, said, ''We are absolutely delighted that Arnold Palmer will once again be on the first tee at Augusta, a place where he belongs, and among thousands that traced their love of the game to his inspiration.''
The tradition of an honorary starter began in 1963 and has been performed by six players -- Jock Hutchison, Fred McLeod, Byron Nelson, Gene Sarazen, Ken Venturi and Sam Snead.
Asked if he might be tempted to hit his tee shot and keep on playing, Palmer said: ''You know, I'm not too smart, but I'm not stupid. I think I'll just let it go wherever it goes.''
